page.title: 02TYPICAL HOUSING OF AREA
page.content: In 1860, Archibald Hood came from Scotland to the Rhondda and sunk the Glamorgan Collieries. Men came from all over to work in the mines and Hood , being a fair master, had to quickly build rows of terraced houses for his workers. They were first built from local stone and later brick, made in the local Scotch(Glamorgan) Colliery. These terraces are unique in the Rhondda. The front of the houses overlook large gardens purposely made for the people to be self-sufficient. They have, however, no front entrances The main entrance to the houses is at the back of the house. Today most of the people of Llwynypia still live in these terraces The old toilets which were opposite the back of the house have been made into car ports. This is because the lanes are far too narrow to park cars.
